body: It's a bug in the version class I suspect, will debug when I get back to the computer

Looking at `packaging`, [here's what `in` does](https://github.com/pypa/packaging/blob/456f94fc0aacaaf3d5da6e833e8043c3e5ce1c2b/packaging/specifiers.py#L743-L773
) on a `SpecifierSet`:

```python
    def contains(
        self, item: UnparsedVersion, prereleases: Optional[bool] = None
    ) -> bool:

        # Ensure that our item is a Version or LegacyVersion instance.
        if not isinstance(item, (LegacyVersion, Version)):
            item = parse(item)

        # Determine if we're forcing a prerelease or not, if we're not forcing
        # one for this particular filter call, then we'll use whatever the
        # SpecifierSet thinks for whether or not we should support prereleases.
        if prereleases is None:
            prereleases = self.prereleases

        # We can determine if we're going to allow pre-releases by looking to
        # see if any of the underlying items supports them. If none of them do
        # and this item is a pre-release then we do not allow it and we can
        # short circuit that here.
        # Note: This means that 1.0.dev1 would not be contained in something
        #       like >=1.0.devabc however it would be in >=1.0.debabc,>0.0.dev0
        if not prereleases and item.is_prerelease:
            return False

        # We simply dispatch to the underlying specs here to make sure that the
        # given version is contained within all of them.
        # Note: This use of all() here means that an empty set of specifiers
        #       will always return True, this is an explicit design decision.
        return all(s.contains(item, prereleases=prereleases) for s in self._specs)
```

note the:

>  Note: This use of all() here means that an empty set of specifiers will always return True, this is an explicit design decision.

but the early short-circuit here:

```python
        if not prereleases and item.is_prerelease:
            return False
```

In the case of `pytest-qt`, `Version(plugin_dist_info[spec.name]).is_prerelease` is `True`, while it is `False` for `pytest-bdd`.

pytest does `spec = Requirement(required_plugin)` and then uses `spec.specifier` to get a `SpecifierSet` from that. It looks like those by default don't accept prereleases at all.

What do you think about:

```diff
diff --git i/src/_pytest/config/__init__.py w/src/_pytest/config/__init__.py
index 144f1c9d1..687b16a37 100644
--- i/src/_pytest/config/__init__.py
+++ w/src/_pytest/config/__init__.py
@@ -1270,14 +1270,17 @@ def _validate_plugins(self) -> None:
         missing_plugins = []
         for required_plugin in required_plugins:
             try:
-                spec = Requirement(required_plugin)
+                req = Requirement(required_plugin)
             except InvalidRequirement:
                 missing_plugins.append(required_plugin)
                 continue
 
-            if spec.name not in plugin_dist_info:
+            specifier = req.specifier
+            specifier.prereleases = True
+
+            if req.name not in plugin_dist_info:
                 missing_plugins.append(required_plugin)
-            elif Version(plugin_dist_info[spec.name]) not in spec.specifier:
+            elif Version(plugin_dist_info[req.name]) not in specifier:
                 missing_plugins.append(required_plugin)
 
         if missing_plugins:

```

If that sounds reasonable, I'll see if I can add a test for this and open a PR.

rename.from: required_plugins false-positive with VCS-installed plugins (due to setuptools-scm?)
rename.to: required_plugins false-positive with prereleases of plugins

issue.title: Test against bleeding edge dependencies in CI

labels.name: component: infrastructure
labels.description: Issues related to development scripts, CI, servers, etc.

labels.name: priority: 1 - middle
labels.description: Issues which should be done at some point, but aren't that important.

repository.name: qutebrowser
repository.description: A keyboard-driven, vim-like browser based on Python and Qt.

issue.body:
Would be great to have a ~weekly CI job testing against VCS versions of dependencies, so that any issues can be caught and reported before releases.

Also see: [[PyQt] Snapshot Wheels Now Available](https://www.riverbankcomputing.com/pipermail/pyqt/2021-March/043703.html).

I started some work on this, but it's currently blocked by:

- [3.0.0: BytesWarning in _null_values comparison 路 Issue #271 路 pyparsing/pyparsing](https://github.com/pyparsing/pyparsing/issues/271) (can be worked around by skipping affected versions)
- [required_plugins false-positive with prereleases of plugins 路 Issue #8456 路 pytest-dev/pytest](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/8456)

body: it looks reasonable at first glance, thanks for checking
instead of mutating `.prereleases = true` one can do `specifier.contains(version, prereleases=True)` (I at least would prefer that)

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing
